Introduction Various research challenges are critical for the cancer care continuum and �nding treatment at various levels of the most threatening disease to human health [1]. Following an accumulation of mutational, genetic, and epigenetic alterations, abnormal cells begin to divide without control and soon form a mass of extra-tissue (or tumor) that can spread to the entire body through bloodstream and lymph and becomes deadly [2-5]. Disease-speci�c mutational events can serve as reliable cancer biomarkers for diagnosis [6-7], which is especially important given that human cells can develop multiple types of primary cancerous tumors [8- 10]. However, the high diversity of genetic mutations in mitochondrial DNA, non-coding RNA, microRNA, ubiquitin, RNA editing, peptide mutation, spliceosome and/or RNA splicing, and phenotype-speci�city of drug sensitivity, which is largely dependent on tumor-stroma interactions, are reasons for cancer treatment di�culties [11-18]. The effects of radiation, nanomedicine, nanoparticles, extracellular vesicle bioengineering, gene therapy, thermal ablation, and particularly immunotherapy and chemotherapy on the treatment of cancer have thus been the subject of numerous studies [19-22]. Cancer treatment has given special focus to immunotherapy, or the increase of T cells' ability for antigen-directed toxicity [23]. This is also important since, in addition to the disease's targeting of the immune system, anticancer strategies such as chemotherapy and radiotherapy also negatively affect it [24-26]. Chemotherapy in particular is the cancer treatment most likely to impair immunity and cause neutropenia [27-28]. Chemotherapy is used to treat cancer cells that divide quickly, but it also affects many healthy cells in the body, including neutrophils, making it di�cult to treat infections while receiving chemotherapy [29]. This makes any strategy to try dealing with the preservation of immune system for chemotherapy extremely relevant.Page 3/37Similar to radiotherapy, "chemo" has a temporary effect on the immune system, and after a few months, one may regain normal or almost normal immune functioning depending on the type of treatment, how long it lasts, and other variables including smoking, age, and general patient health problems [30]. As described for cyclophosphamide, or cyclophosphane, an antineoplastic in chemicals known as Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drug (DMARD) used to treat various forms of cancers from lymphoma to sarcoma, and to suppress the immune system, in a manner similar to aging, chemotherapy is thought to shorten lifespan due to medical complications like heart disease, pulmonary �brosis and/or endocrine system-related disease [31-32]. The drug cyclosphosphamide, commonly known as Neosar® or Cytoxan® (CTX), is also used in veterinary medicine [33], making the study it undertook a good illustration of how human and animal medicine can complement one another in cancer research. More than half of all cancer patients receive ionizing radiation therapy, which results in late in�ammatory reactions and/or over time, especially with high dose rate radiation, the patient's immune system may develop disorders linked to in�ammation [34]. Cyclophosphamide-chemotherapy, which is likely used to treat the other half of cancer cases, has the potential to have negative effects on the lungs, most frequently manisfesting as diffuse alveolar destruction [35]. When the dose of CTX is increased, there is a risk that chemotherapeutic resistance will develop [36]. After using CTX for a long time, there is even a risk of developing another cancer, and CTX-chemo is known to permanently affect the growth of neurons and sensory abilities [37-38]. Concerns about immune system modi�cation and cell transplantation are yet another signi�cant CTX-related source of worry. In allogeneic hematopoietic blood-forming stem cell transplants, post-transplant CTX changes immunological markers and results in poorer T cell reconstitution [39]. Finding novel approaches to continue using radiotherapy and/or chemotherapy, which are essential to promoting T cell lymphocyte activity in order to treat the disease, while preserving the patient's natural barriers and immune functions to �ght other infections and/or preserve stem cells in case of transplantation, is thus one of the most di�cult challenges for cancer research [40-46]. The idea of employing complementary and/or alternative, more natural medicine to treat cancer is not new; microbe mediated tumor therapy, which treats cancer by injecting bacteria nearby, is well known [47]. However, microbe-based approaches may be increasing popularity in our contemporary modern lifestyles. Bacteria-mediated tumor therapy has been practiced for more than a century. Nowadays, it looks as simple as that; the good bacteria move to the tumor and multiply there, activating the patient's immune system [48]. But things might be trickier than that. Microbiological studies show that the gut microbiota is necessary for the effectiveness of CTX-chemotherapy [49]. Therefore, understanding how the CTX drug affects the gut microbiota and immune system and how the gut and immune system can be protected from chemotherapy remain critical. Given the relationship between the immune system and the gut, gut bacteria (or micro�ora) have also emerged as a key target for enhancing T cells and in�uencing the effectiveness of cancer therapies [50-51]. It has been proven through the use of several cancer model studies that a healthy gut �ora signi�cantly affects the effectiveness of anticancer medications like immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs), CTX and other phosphamide chemical drugs [52-55]. The current Lactobacillus study is comparable to any commercially available probiotic preparation, such as L. rhamnosus, which is known to limit the growth of cancer cells in a dose- and time-dependent manner [56]. In terms of enhancing the gut microbiota and preventing tumor genesis, it is comparable to L. rhamnosus GG, the microbe model of cancer that has been the subject of the most research [56-59]. In this novel and di�cult research area, which mostly focuses on colon cancer, an uniform 'probiotic' strategy is intended to prevent patient selection in light of the various chemical treatments and unique host responses to gut modi�cation [60]. Because of this, we eventually developed a unique 3L Lactobacillus bioproduct for use in medicine, which is a natural combination of L. acidophilus, L. casei, and L. plantarum. It has been shown that this product ("3L") signi�cantly improves the physiological and biochemical state of hyperlipidemic animals. In mice, "3L" has been shown to signi�cantly reduce blood lipid levels, cholesterolemia, the LDL/HDL ratio, and weight gain in addition to promoting healthy gut �ora [61-62]. Rodents are the best models for examining diseases linked to obesity and metabolic problems in humans [63]. They are also excellent research subjects for investigations into immunology and immunotherapy for human cancer [64]. As a result, we used �ve different groups of rats as our experimental models to investigate the effects of 3L on intestinal gut �ora and CTX chemotherapy, as a prelude to a more comprehensive examination of the effect of 3L on the immune system. In this pilot experiment, we examined the gut microbiota following chemotherapy using Illumina MiSeq sequencing that is optimized for full complete microbial genome applications. Our results showed that CTX treatment considerably altered the composition of the microbiome. This is related to a prior study using the same groups of rats, which revealed that treatment withPage 4/37CTX altered the immune system [65]. The rats we used in this pilot experiment were healthy rats that received the chemical substance cyclophosphamide CTX; they were not sick or malignant. Three doses were tested: low (L), medium (M), and high (H) on the microbiome of chemotherapy rat models because the effects on leukocytes, T helper cells, interleukins, and TNF-alpha were dose-dependent [65]. With regard to the group of animals treated from one week to one month (28 days) with the high dose of Lactobacillus preparation (H-dose: 5 mg/kg), as opposed to the group of animals given CTX alone, white blood cells counts in particular rose [65]. Then, we looked at how 3L and chemotherapy affected the intestinal gut �ora and health of CTX-injured rats. The overall results of the Lactobacillus+CTX chemotherapy treatment were favorable to a degree that had not previously been noted. The microbial gut �ora signi�cantly improved when the dose of 3L (acidophilus, casei, and plantarum) was increased. Using a microecosystem like these three Lactobacilli did not treat cancer in the rats we utilized since they were normal, not tumor or cancer model animals. However, despite CTX, which is chemotherapy used to treat tumors, it helped to enhance intestinal health. A pharmacological bioproduct rich in three Lactobacillus strains has been reported to considerably support a healthy gut microbiome despite CTX treatment (chemotheray). In order to prevent a chemotherapy-induced changed gut, we suggest a new bioactive microbial natural medicinal product that will �rst be evaluated in sick malignant rats and later on humans. This medicine may be used to cure tumors or cancer or, at the very least, prevent the altered gut caused by CTX chemotherapy. When chemotherapy is envisioned as the primary or perhaps only way to prevent cancer development, the burden of threat to human health increases. Using one or more anti-cancer chemical drugs, such as cyclophosphamide (cytophosphane, CTX), kills lymphoma or any cancer cells, but it also kills or seriously alters the patient immune system, potentially limiting life and health expectancies, just like the disease. This is shown in a previous study from Zhang et al. in rats where CTX was shown to alter several immune marker indicators like the number of white blood cells, CD4+/CD8+ratio, the serum levels of interleukin 6 (IL-6) and interleukin gene expression [see 65]. In this previous study, which used the same chemotherapy rat model (see Fig. 1), the CTX-increased expression of TNF-alpha cytokine, an endocrine mediator of in�ammatory and immune functions, known to regulate cell growth, cell signaling, but with many side effects of cytotoxicity in transformed cells, was another indication of immune attacks in CTX conditions [65]. Importantly, we show that Lactobacillus treatments are particularly effective at maintaining healthy gut �ora in the rat intestine, allowing us to establish strong healthy conditions in rats despite chemo (see Figs. 2-4 & S1-S6).
